... (H) Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen,
'd like to welcome you to the Kentucky Horse Park,
 the Hall of Champions presentation.
e have four geldings and one stallion that we'll present for you this afternoon,
and as we bring them out,
l give you the history on each one,
please feel free to take all the pictures that you want,
to ask questions.
first horse here today at the Hall of Champions,
ur only thoroughbred stallion.
his is Bold Forbes.
H) Bold Forbes is a dark bay or brown stallion,
he was foaled in nineteen seventy-three.
He is by the stallion Irish Castle,
out of the unraced mare Comely Nell.
He was bred by Lee Eaton,
Red Bull Stables.
This grandson of Bold Ruler was entered into a sale in July of nineteen seventy-four.
H) Mister Estaban Tizol,
nker and real estate developer from Puerto Rico,
liked Bold Forbes' pedigree.
he liked this horse so much,
that he decided he was going to buy him,
atter what the cost.
H) The cost ended up being fifteen-thousand two-hundred dollars,
and Bold Forbes was then shipped to El Commandante racetrack in San Juan Puerto Rico.
(H) In Bold Forbes' very first start in Puerto Rico as a two-year-old,
he went off at odds of thirty-five to one,
nd he won that race by seventeen lengths.
(H) He was entered into four more races,
e won them all,
and in doing so,
was named champion two-year-old in Puerto Rico.
. (H) Well El Commandante is the only racetrack in Puerto Rico,
) so it didn't take Bold Forbes too long to run out of competition.
. (H) So in the summer of nineteen seventy-five,
 was shipped to New York,
 his new trainer Laz Barrera.
. (H) In New York he won the Freemont Stakes,
d the Saratoga Special,
fore he injured his shins,
d was given the rest of the year off.
. (H) Well all of Bold Forbes's races up to this point had been sprints,
 six furlong races.
) The Kentucky Derby is a much longer race,
 a mile and a quarter.
. So as a three-year-old,
rbes wasn't given much of a chance at all in the Kentucky Derby.
. (H) But his trainer had more confidence in him than that,
) and with Angel Cordero junior in the saddle,
) Bold Forbes won the Kentucky Derby,
 odds of seventeen to one,
. one length in front of the leader,
 Honest Pleasure.
. (H) The Preakness however was a disappointment for Bold Forbes.
 cut his left hind heel during the race,
t he still managed to run third.
. (H) But when the Belmont rolled around,
 had that all healed up,
d he won the Belmont stakes by a neck.
. (H) In October,
rbes was entered into the Vosburgh Handicap,
d again he severely bruised his right hind foot.
) Again he ran a very game third,
t after this race,
 was considered too valuable a breeding stallion to risk any more injury.
) So he was retired to stud from the track.
. (H) Bold Forbes was syndicated to stud for a hundred and thirty thousand dollars per share,
) and he stood his entire career at Arthur Hancock Stone Farm.
. (H) As a stallion,
ld Forbes produced a champion filly Tiffany Lass,
winner of over half a million dollars,
) Bold Apparel,
champion filly in Italy,
) Air Forbes One,
d over two-hundred other winners.
) .. Bold Forbes is a winner of over half a million dollars,
 just two years on the racetrack.
) He was in eighteen races,
d had thirteen wins,
d was never worse than third.
. (H) He was retired from stud duty in the spring of nineteen ninety-one.
 (H) He is twenty-one years old,
d stands fifteen point three hands tall.
 (H) Ladies and gentlemen,
e nineteen seventy-six Kentucky Derby winner,
 Bold Forbes.

.
) Our next horse is the first horse to retire here to the Hall of Champions,
at is not a racehorse.
. This is Imperator.
d he is a five-gaited American Saddlebred showhorse.
. (H) Perry,
 he is commonly called,
 by the sire Supreme Sultan,
o is buried in front of the saddlehorse museum here at the Horse Park.
 (H) He is out of the dam Empress Wing,
 and she is by the great sire Wing Commander.
) Only Wing Commander holds more world grand championships than Imperator.
 (H) Perry was born in Wilmette Illinois,
) and he was purchased there as a two-year-old,
 his owner,
ctor Geraldine Meanor,
) and then sent to his trainer,
n Harris,
 Simpsonville Kentucky.
 (H) Now Perry and Mister Harris had a very special bond that they shared.
) They both had the same birthday.
) And as the years went past,
d Imperator's popularity increased,
) Mister Harris didn't get too upset when Perry received more birthday cards and presents than he did.
. (H) Being five-gaited means that Perry performs the three natural gaits,
 the walk trot and canter,
) plus two manmade gaits,
e slow gait and the rack.
. (H) The only difference in these gaits are the speed at which they're performed.
. Perry's greatest accomplishment was winning the five-gaited world grand championship four times.
) And he has also been reserve world champion five times.
. (H) He was shown eighty-five times,
 forty-four shows around the country.
) He has sixty-eight blue ribbons,
irteen seconds,
d very rarely was he ever worse than third.
. (H) Now the first time Perry was shown,
 was very wild and inexperienced,
d he stepped on just about every foot in the show ring.
) And he even chased the judges out of the ring on several occasions.
. (H) But the second time he was shown,
 had improved so much,
) the judges said he would have won if he'd been lying on his back,
 with all four feet stuck up in the air.
. (H) Perry's most beautiful characteristic during his show career was his tail.
 (H) At the highlight of his career,
) .. Perry's tail was fourteen feet long,
d could be wrapped completely around his body.
. If you wanted to take a picture of all of Perry,
) you had to take two pictures to include all of his tail.
 (H) When Perry was retired,
ster Harris cut his tail,
 make it easier to care for,
) and he was able to make three false tails from the hair he had taken from Perry's tail.
 (H) Well Perry had been retired here for about two years,
) but had never had a formal retirement.
) So in August of nineteen ninety-one,
rry was formally retired at the world championship horse show in Louisville Kentucky.
 (H) That night,
perator and his trainer,
ster Don Harris,
) stepped into the ring,
e last time together,
) and were both named the American Saddlebred horse and trainer for the decade of the nineteen-eighties.
. (H) Perry is now twenty years old,
d stands fifteen point three hands tall.
) Ladies and gentlemen,
e four-time world grand champion,
 Imperator.

. (H) Our next horse is one of our two thoroughbred geldings here at the Hall of Champions,
is is Forego.
. (H) Forego is by the Argentine stallion Forli,
 and he is out of the champion race mare Lady Golconda.
. He was bred and raised at Claiborne Farm in Paris Kentucky.
 (H) Due to Forego's large size,
 was not raced as a two-year-old,
) because his owners thought they would give him more time to mature.
. (H) He started his racing career as a three-year-old.
d he ran well enough to be entered in the nineteen seventy-three Kentucky Derby.
. (H) Well you may recall that this was the year that a horse named Secretariat won the Kentucky Derby,
) on his way to sweeping the Triple Crown.
. (H) Well Forego wasn't as successful as Secretariat that day,
) But he did run a fine race.
. (H) He was involved in a bumping incident,
 the horses left the starting gate.
) He recovered from that,
 but he and another horse,
r Native,
) bumped through the entire stretch,
d both horses ended in a photo finish for third.
. After the steward's inquiry,
) Forego had to settle for fourth,
 because the steward said the bumping was all his fault.
. (H) The older Forego got,
e better he got,
d he became one of the greatest handicap horses to ever race.
) He has also been voted one of the top ten racehorses of the century.
. (H) Being a handicap horse means that Forego ha- --
rego had to carry a lot of extra weight,
) over whatever distance he was asked to run,
) in order to give the other horses more of a chance.
. (H) He was in thirty-four handicap events,
d thirty times,
 was the high-weighted horse.
. (H) The most weight Forego ever had to carry to victory,
s a hundred and thirty-seven pounds.
) And that was in the nineteen seventy-six Marlboro Cup.
. (H) Well before the race it had rained,
d the track was sloppy,
) and Forego was always a little wimpy about getting his feet wet.
. So as the field turned for home,
 looked just as if he was hopelessly beaten,
me ten lengths behind the leader Honest Pleasure.
. (H) Honest Pleasure had been the Kentucky Derby favorite that year,
. He was three years younger than Forego,
) and was carrying almost twenty pounds less in weight.
. But determined to win,
) Forego made up that last quarter mile,
 twenty-two seconds flat,
) and he beat Honest Pleasure at the wire.
. The jockey that rode Forego,
e great Willy Shoemaker,
) said there wasn't a horse alive,
at could've beaten Forego on that day.
. (H) Forego was named horse of the year,
ree consecutive years,
 nineteen seventy-four seventy-five and seventy-six.
) And he has also been champion sprinter,
 well as champion handicap horse.
. (H) An Eclipse Award is the highest honor a thoroughbred can receive.
) And Forego holds eight Eclipse Awards,
ich is more than any other horse.
. Forego retired in nineteen seventy-eight,
) with earnings of over one point nine million dollars,
ich made him the second richest thoroughbred in history at that time,
hind Kelso.
. (H) He was inducted into racing's hall of fame in nineteen seventy-nine.
. (H) Forego is one of our senior citizens here at the Hall of Champions,
) he is twenty-four years old,
d stands a very impressive (H) seventeen point one hands tall.
. Ladies and gentlemen,
e great handicap horse,
. Forego.

RA:	.. He was put down,

. and and they put him down.
. (H) Our next horse to come out today,
 our other thoroughbred gelding to be retired here,
) and you'll see that he's a lot smaller than Forego.
. This is John Henry.
. (H) John Henry is the horse that comes from very humble beginnings.
) He is by the stallion Old Bob Bowers,
o was not much of a racehorse or a stallion either.
 (H) And he is out of the brood mare Once Double,
) who outside of John Henry,
d very little success as a brood mare.
. (H) John was born on March ninth nineteen seventy-five,
 Golden Chance Farm in Paris Kentucky.
 (H) The farm kept John until nineteen seventy-six,
en he was consigned to the Keenenland January Mixed Sale.
 (H) Now this sale is not a very good time to sell a horse,
) it's usually when people try to sell the horses they don't think are worth feeding through the winter.
. (H) So because of his small size,
s lack of pedigree,
t most of all,
s very nasty disposition,
) John brought only eleven hundred dollars.
. (H) And from the time of this first sale,
til May nineteen seventy-eight,
) John was sold,
er half a dozen times,
cause nobody wanted him,
) and nobody could get along with him.
. (H) But in May of nineteen seventy-eight,
New York businessman,
m Rubin,
) decided it would be fun to own a racehorse.
 (H) Well Mister Rubin didn't know anything about horses,
) and the only thing he knew about racing,
 where the valet parking was.
. (H) So he bought John Henry,
er the telephone,
ght unseen,
r twenty-five thousand dollars.
 (H) John then went to New York,
 his first trainer Bobby Donato.
 (H) In his very first New York start,
 won a twenty-five thousand dollar claiming race,
er the dirt,
 one and a half lengths.
 (H) His next race was on turf,
) which John preferred to run on,
d again he won,
t this time by fourteen lengths.
. (H) Well a group of horsemen who knew more about racing than Mister Rubin did,
) advised him to send John west,
 where the turf racing was more lucrative,
re competitive,
d run all year long.
. So in late nineteen seventy-nine,
) John headed west,
 his new trainer,
 Ronald McAnally.
. (H) In nineteen eighty,
hn won over nine-hundred thousand dollars.
 (H) In nineteen eighty-one,
hn won the very first Arlington Million,
) over one point seven million dollars,
d was voted horse of the year.
 (H) In nineteen eighty-two,
d nineteen eighty-three,
hn had some injuries,
d only won four races,
) but they mounted up to one point two million dollars.
. (H) And when Mister McAnally wanted to bring John Henry back as a nine-year-old,
) folks were pretty skeptical about his chances of being competitive at this age.
.. (H) Well John did lose his first race that year,
(H) but he went on to have his best year ever on the racetrack.
... (H) He won six graded stakes,
including a repeat victory in the Arlington Million,
(H) over two point three million dollars,
and again was voted horse of the year.
... (H) When John was retired in nineteen eighty-four,
he was the world's richest thoroughbred in history.
(H) With earnings over six point five million dollars.
... (H) Since then Alisheba has beat his record,
but John is still the richest gelding.
... (H) John holds seven Eclipse Awards,
which is second only to Forego's eight,
(H) and was inducted into the racing hall of fame in nineteen ninety.
... John was also named the thoroughbred horse of the decade,
for the nineteen eighties.
... (H) John has been retired here for eight years now.
(H) He is nineteen years old,
and stands a very small=,
(H) fifteen point one hands tall.
.. (H) Ladies and gentlemen,
the great great .. John Henry.

... (H) Our last horse to come out today,
is our standardbred representative,
Rambling Willie.
.. (H) A standardbred races at a trot or a pace,
and they pull a sulky with a driver.
... (H) Willie is a pacer.
... (H) Willie was born in Monroeville Indiana,
and he began his racing career as a to-year-old,
for his owner Raymond Gibson.
(H) He had four starts with two seconds and two thirds,
(H) so he did show some promise,
but Mister Gibson decided to sell Willie as a three-year-old.
... (H) Willie was sold to a hall of fame trainer and driver,
Mister Robert Farrington,
for fifteen thousand dollars.
(H) But not long after he bought him,
Mister Farrington decided he'd spent too much money on this horse,
(H) so he called a friend of his from Cincinnati Ohio,
Mister Paul Sebert,
(H) and he tried to talk Mister Sebert into buying a half interest in Willie.
... (H) Well Mister Sebert had owned horses before,
(H) and his luck had been pretty bad.
.. (H) The first horse he owned died,
before it made it to the racetrack,
(H) and the second horse he owned made it to the races,
and she ran and ran,
but just couldn't win anything,
so he sold her.
.. (H) And after he sold her,
she went on to win her next four starts in a row for her new owner.
... (H) Well Mister Sebert did buy a half interest in Willie though,
(H) and things didn't start off so well there either.
... Willie was being raced at county fairs,
in Ohio and Indiana,
(H) and was being beaten on a regular basis.
... (H) Well around this time Mister Farrington's wife Vivian was having a birthday,
(H) and he was trying to decide what to get her.
.. (H) So Mister Farrington decided that a good present for Vivian,
would be the other half of Willie.
... (H) Well Vivian was a very religious person,
(H) and her father at that time was the minister of a nearby church.
.. (H) So Vivian decided,
that if Willie ever had any success at the racetrack,
(H) she would donate ten percent,
of her half of Willie's earnings,
to her father's church.
... (H) And that's when Willie's racing career took off.

) then right at that yellow line.
) And you're now standing over the second-largest water pipe in the world,
) and it's called a penstock.
. More about that a little bit later.
 (H) The Colorado River,
ows in this direction.
) In order to build a dam here,
e very first thing they had to do=,
) was to get rid of that river.
 (H) So they came up here above where the dam was to be built,
) and drilled and blasted out,
ur diversion tunnels.
) Two on either si=de,
) into the canyon wall,
ound where the dam was to be built,
) out in the river down below.
) Each one of these tunnels were drilled and blasted out at fifty-six feet in diameter,
) and then lined with three feet of concrete.
 (H) You're now standing in one of those old diversion tunnels.
. (H) They then came up here,
d they built a cofferdam about a hundred feet high,
) to force this river into these diversion tunnels.
) Came back down here,
ilt the other part of that cofferda=m,
) about sixty-five feet high=,
) to keep this water from backing into the work area.
) They now had from he=re,
) to here where they could build a dam.
 (H) They pumped the water out of this area,
) and excavated down another hundred and thirty-five feet to bedrock.
 (H) Okay folks,
 you will please,
ke a look at this picture taken during construction,
 (H) looks like a series of boxes or blocks,
acked one on top of the other,
 (H) and those are wooden concrete fo=rms.
) Each one of those forms are exactly five feet high,
) but they did vary in area somewhat,
) because they did not build the dam right straight across the river,
) from canyon wall to canyon wa=ll,
) they built it in the form of an arc.
. And it's called an arch .. gravity design dam.
) Where the force of the water,
ming down the Colorado River hits the face of the dam,
) and tends to try to drive these wingtips further into the canyon wa=ll.
 (H) It's a very strong design.
. They did build two concrete mixing plants here,
) they did pour concrete for twenty-four hours a day,
ven days a week,
) three hundred and sixty-five days a year.
) For two years,
 less ... six days.
) Now every bit of that concrete came down in individual eight-cubic-yard bucketloads.
) Eight cubic yards of concrete into one of these forms,
) the smallest of which is twenty-two by twenty-five feet,
) only filled that form up about three or four inches deep.
 (H) So there goes that story you may have hea=rd,
) that there are workers buried in the concrete here.
 Couldn't possibly happen.
 (H) But what they did bury in that freshly poured concrete,
) was one-inch steel water pipe.
 (H) They came down here in this lower cofferda=m,
)= and they built an i=ce plant.
 Capable of making a thousand tons of ice a day.
) They used that ice,
 chill the water,
) that they forced through that pipe in this newly placed concrete.
 (H) As concrete ha=rdens,
 cures as we call it,
) it produces heat.
. The more you can control that heat,
) the better job of curing you're going to get.
 (H) So they used the chilled water method,
 taking that cold water,
) forcing it through that pipe in that newly placed concrete,
) picking up some of that heat,
) then carrying that heat out and away.
 (H) They felt if they did not use a method such as this,
 that it would've taken approximately (H) one hundred and fifty years,
r the concrete .. in the interior part of the dam (H) to cool down.
 (H) So the system did work.
. And then it hardened,
d they remove these wooden forms,
 <X they X> left voids.
rtically and horizontally these forms came together,
) those voids were filled with grout.
der high pressure.
. Grout being a mixture of concrete and water.
. (H) When this is done,
u have what we call a modified monolithic pour,
) or basically a solid block of concrete,
) which when completed would be six hundred and sixty feet across the base,
) fourty-five feet across the top,
) twelve hundred and fourty-four feet from wingtip to wingtip,
) seven hundred and twenty-six point four feet high.
. <MRC Six point six million tons of concrete MRC>.
. That's enough concrete to build a two-lane highway (H) from New York City to San Francisco.
. O=r,
t another way,
) a four-foot wide sidewalk from the North Pole to the South Pole.
 (H) Then they had to protect that concrete a little bit,
) the next thing they had to do then is build a couple of spillways.
) As you got out of your cars or your busses this afternoon,
u may have noticed those spillways.
) Here they are,
e on either side.
 (H) What they did,
 they came in here,
d they blocked these diversion tunnels off in this area through here,
. (H) closed these gates up here,
) now this yellow part is forever under water.
) Underneath that lake out there,
d completely useless.
) But they did incorporate,
to the design of the dam,
) the balance of those diversion tunnels,
 (H) using these outer two as spillway tunnels.
) Now these spillways were built,
 that the top of the spi=llway,
) is twenty-seven feet lower than the top of the dam.
 (H) This assures us that n- any excess water coming down the Colorado River,
) rather than overtopping the dam,
) overtops these spillways on either side,
) goes into the canyon wall,
ound the dam,
) out in the river down below.
 (H) Each one of these spillways is capable of handling (H) two hundred th=ousand cubic feet per second of water.
 (H) That's the same amount of water that goes over Niagara Falls.
 (H) <X Falls X> three times higher than Niagara Falls does,
) time that water reaches this area down in here,
) it is flowing at between one hundred,
) and one hundred and twenty miles an hour.
. (H) Okay we have protected the spillways,
) now they had to get some water,
 (H) %- into the power plant.
. What they did is they built four intake towers.
) Two on either side of the (H) river,
 ledges above the river,
) each of those towers that you saw out there in that lake,
. are three hundred and ninety-five feet high.
. Each with two-eleven-by-thirty-two-foot gates in them,
) one gate near the bottom,
e about half way up,
) to let the water in.
) The water then coming into the penstocks,
) like the one we're standing over right now.
. (H) This penstock,
u can see on either side of us out here,
) is three stories high,
 thirty feet in diameter,
de of two-and-three-quarter-inch steel boilerplate.
 (H) Made in section twenty-two feet long.
 Each section weighing approximately (H) a hundred and fifty tons.
) Each of these twenty-two-foot sections is joined to the next section,
) using pressure pins like thi=s.
 (H) The water pressure in that penstock out there this afternoon,
) approximately two hundred and thirty-four pounds per square inch.
. (H) Okay we have the water this far,
w we divert that into thirteen-foot penstocks or water pipes,
) each one of em going to a turbine.
. (H) The force of the water turns the turbine,
ich turns the rotor in the generator,
) and generates power.
. The water then coming on the tailrace,
 saw it up there,
) and going on downstream to be used at least .. six more times,
fore it reaches the Mexican border,
) to generate more power.
 (H) Good clean .. reusable non-polluting source of energy.
. (TSK) (H) The cost of the project.
. A hundred and seventy-five million dollars.
. I say project,
cause that includes the building of the dam,
) the building of Boulder City about seven miles up the road,
) the highway and the railway from Las Vegas out here to the dam site,
) and in southern California they built the All-American Canal,
) which takes water to the people and the crops,
 of the Imperial and Coachella Valleys.
) This money was borrowed on a fifty-year term at three-percent interest,
) and was paid off in fu=ll in nineteen eighty-seven.
. The people who worked here,
d they did work twenty-four hours a day,
) average twenty-four-hour work force was about thirty-five hundred men.
 (H) The most they had at any one time was when they were pouring concrete,
) fourty-three hundred men.
. (H) The laborers on the job made fifty cents an hour.
 (H) Highest paid man on the project was a power shovel operator,
) at a dollar and a qu=arter an hour.
. (H) Out of each man's paycheck,
e contractor did deduct each day,
) a dollar and sixty cents.
) Because the contractor was feeding,
) and housing the men in Boulder City,
) and taking them back and forth out here to the job site.
. They did have ninety-six .. industrial deaths.
 The biggest single category of death was classified as falling material.
) Basically falling rock.
. But they did have some killed by explosion,
) some by drowning,
me by electrocution,
) and other types of accidents you might expect to have.
) On a job of this magnitude.
. They did complete the project,
o years ahead of schedule,
d under budget.
) Started in early nineteen thirty-one,
) completed in late nineteen thirty-five.
) Just twelve days short .. of five years.
. (H) Do I have any questions.
:	... What's this overhead pipe here X.
:	(H) The overhead pipe.
) That's the fresh air pipe.
 (H) ... In the summerti=me,
) the temperature of the air outside gets to be as high as a hundred and twenty degrees.
) So they bring that fresh air i=n,
) and they pass that fresh air over a sump at the base of the dam,
) the water in that sump is a constant fifty-three degrees.
) It cools that air down to between sixty-eight and seventy-two degrees,
) then they force it back throughout the dam.
) So it's %air-conditioning without refrigeration.
ke a big evaporative cooler or swamp cooler.

EN:	(H) <X Well X>,
.. % it leaks all the time.
(H) You see concrete's porous.
(H) And because concrete's porous,
there's water coming through at all times.
(H) But that's good.
(H) Because if <X there're X> no moisture in concrete,
(H) it dries out,
an=d .. spalls and chips,
an=d .. turns to powder.
(H) Wouldn't make a very good dam.
(H) So as long as that lake is back there,
forcing that water through the concrete at all times,
(H) it keeps that concrete in a stage of what we call being green.
(H) Green concrete's very strong.
(H) So we have a good strong dam.

EN:	.. [Yes].

UD_2:	... Have they ever had to use the spillway?
EN:	Okay.
.. Folks,
the question is,
did they ever have to use the spillway.
.. (H) Yes.
Just once in the history of the dam,
and that was nineteen eighty-three.
... (H) What happened that year,
(H) is they had a very heavy snowpack in the Rocky Mountains,
(H) .. and that was followed by rain and hot weather,
(H) which created a flooding condition.
(H) We had more water coming down the Colorado River system,
(H) than they could put through the power plant.
.. (H) Every reservoir in the Colorado River system was full to overflowing that year.
.. (H) On July second,
... water overtopped our spillways out here.
(H) Six days later,
it was going over four and a half feet high.
(H) And that went on for sixty-six days.
(H) At the end of that time there was no damage to the dam,
(H) or to the power plant,
(H) but further on downstream where people had built in the floodplain,
(H) they did have thirty million dollars worth of damage,
(H) but no loss of life.
... But that flood's what left that white line around the lake out there.
... That white line indicates it was going over the spillways,
(H) four and a half feet above floodstage.
(H) It gives a false impression,
and makes it look like the lake of the level is low.
Or level the lake .. of the low.
.. (H) Actually we're eight feet above normal,
for this time of year.
